hedline.hl1: The best, the brightest and 'The Bell Curve.'

block.p: Worries over American citizens' declining I.Q.'s and the supposed consequences for the labor force baffle me. Such fears seem predicated on the canard that in years past the brightest and the best were hired and promoted commensurate with their abilities.

Worries over American citizens' declining I.Q.'s and the supposed consequences for the labor force baffle me. Such fears seem predicated on the canard that in years past the brightest and the best were hired and promoted commensurate with their abilities.

If a high I.Q. is the marker for success in the workplace, why were "Ashkenazi Jews of European origins" (the brightest bulbs, according to the I.Q. devotees) quotaed out of the most prestigious American universities and the most intellectually taxing professions? Why have Asians been excluded from the upper echelons of management? Why, also, were women of every hue and religious persuasion forced out of the workplace or relegated to careers as domestics and secretaries? LAURIE L. MOORE San Francisco
